content.question: Let <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function given by <math alttext="g of x, equals, the integral from, 3 to x, of, open parenthesis, t squared, minus 5 t, minus 14, close parenthesis, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="2.4ex" width="0.0em"></mspace><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>. What is the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of the point of inflection of the graph of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 4.7: Using L'Hospital's Rule for Determining Limits of Indeterminate Forms
